poem:
### A Leave-In Lament

Once vibrant on the shelf, now rare,  
lost in the lore of synthetic care.  
We sought their sleek, unburdened spell,  
but fashions shift, silken tales to tell.  
Yet whispers in the wind remind,  
of tresses gentle, strands refined,  
where leave-ins lingered in their prime,  
a bygone touch, a frozen time.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Why did leave-in hair conditioners fall out of fashion? They are still fabulous | Sali Hughes on beauty A few months ago and on hairdresser’s orders, I went looking for a leave-in conditioner and found they were nearing extinction. Leave-ins seemed to be everywhere a decade or so ago. I could only assume that, like me, most consumers had forgotten how valuable they are in preventing hair damage in return for the lowest possible effort. As I wonder". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
